events.name: Dream Brewery Hackathon
events.description: The love for beer and its craft has been around for ages but nothing has changed much since. Here’s a crazy idea for you. What would happen if we apply technology to this classic drink? Come hack 3 challenges with ABInBev at the Dream Brewery Hackathon on November 7th & 8th and stand a chance to win cash prizes, cool toys & even mentorship support to revolutionise the F&B space!  Use “Free4iOSDev” @ http://Bitly.com/dreambreweryhackathon­ to get FREE tickets to the hack!  PRIZES • The first place team will receive S$2,000 and Apple iWatches  Second Place Team: S$1,000 + Cherokey 4wd Robot Kits • Third Place Team: S$500 + Insectbot Kits • Immediate Qualification: The top 3 winning teams directly qualify for the Budweiser Dream Brewery Pitch Day on February 18, 2016 (pitch your tech and your team could win: S$25,000 funding, incubation & partnership opportunities)  JUDGES  • APAC CIO, ABInBev • APAC Innovation Manager, ABInBev • Tyson Hackwood, Head of Asia, Braintree • Bradley Priest, CTO/Cofounder, TradeGecko • Michael Lints, Venture Partner, Golden Gate Ventures • As well as other top CTOs and VCs
events.location: The Hub Singapore, 128 Prinsep Street, #01-01

events.name: Nov/2015 - Open Space (Coaching and mentoring)
events.description: Open Space Facilitator: Darren Open Space Theme: Coaching “We are uncovering better ways of developing software by doing it and helping others do it… “ In agile development, we emphasis on the need for continuous improvement. To continually improve, we need to learn from others and also teach others to do things in better ways. The theme for this month is in hope to spark discussions around topics like how can we provide assistance across multiple levels within an organization, or how individual seeks for assistance but not limited to just these. Agenda 7:00pm - Networking and pizza 7:30pm - Topic generation 8:00pm - Breakout sessions 10:00pm - End We welcome contributions of drinks and snacks! =) What is Open Space? Open Space is a highly collaborative and self-organised meeting where topics are generated on the spot and discussed by the participants through breakout sessions. For more information read Open Space Technology.  Getting There Marina Bay Financial Centre Tower 2 is just right above of Downtown station along Downtown Line (DT). Building Access The building requires someone from Barclays to allow people into the lift and to the room.Sandeep from Barclays will be at the reception area to help you enter the building. The timings he will make the trip are: 7:00pm, 7:15pm and 7:30pm There is no guarantee of trips after 7:45pm.
events.location: Barclays, 10 Marina Boulevard, #23-01, Marina Bay Financial Centre Tower 2, Singapore

events.description: ** Had to bump this due to logistics and availability **The future of management and configuration of the Microsoft platform is Desired State Configuration. Chef is a configuration management product that is fully leveraging the DSC platform is important to the DevOps movement. There is some great content at learnchef.io which I have wanted to go through for a while but have yet to schedule in. So I am scheduling the time to do it.If you would like to Learn Chef too, join me for this Meetup. I cannot provide any expertise on Chef whatsoever, but I can provide a room with a big screen, food, uninterrupted time to watch the content and go through the labs as well as others to discuss with and expertise on DSC.If this sounds like something you'd like to do please come along, let's learn Chef and progress our journey to DevOps.

events.description: This event is part of DevFest.Asia, Southeast Asia's first community organized web developer festival. Please RSVP here instead. The next talk.js will be on Tuesday 17th November. This is a special edition of talk.js in conjunction with DevFest.Asia and <a>JSConf.Asia</a>. We have a special speaker from Australia and the talks will be longer and more in depth than usual. Do join us for this special occasion! Scheduled Talks: • Cold War: City State - Simon Swain Cold War is a exploration of simulation and graphics. We will dive in to smooth 60fps animation in the browser using html5 canvas, and see how much juice we can squeeze out of our systems. events.name: November Meetup
events.description: My main technical matter will be to talk about how we are building our java monolith app by features (and the underlying tools). I'll explain why we have to do that and why we are choosing to experiment the concept of immutable infra. I will also talk about how we found that devOps are the direct link between the product team and our customers and why we want to automate the delivery pipe as much as we can. My view will be from a devOps perspective but also from a CTO perspective , at a higher level.

events.name: The Cloud and .NET Moment (FREE - DevFest.Asia Edition)
events.description:
This event is part of DevFest.Asia 2015, Southeast Asia's first community organized web developer festival. FREE FOR ALL developers! The next .NET Developers and Azure community meetup will be on Thursday, November 19th, 2015. This is a special edition of .NET developers and Azure community meetup in conjunction with DevFest.Asia 2015. Let's have a Cloud and .NET moment! We have a high caliber speakers from Microsoft, coming down to Singapore, for you all. Do join us for this special Cloud and .NET Moment! Seriously, you might not get this moment again next time. SPEAKER ONE Christian Heilmann: More than 20 years as Web expert, HTML5 and JavaScript expert, spoken at 129 events in 26 countries, a Developer Evangelist - all things for open web, HTML5, writing books, articles, blogs, podcast, Channel 9 (MSDN), YouTube, you name it!   Chris is a Senior Program Manager at Microsoft, working on Microsoft Edge. You want to know what is Microsoft Edge all about, first hand from the person, than you need to join this moment! Ask him! SPEAKER TWO Ryan J. Salva: JS Developer, Apache Cordova Advocate, Visual Studio Program Manager, CrossFitter, SciFi Connoisseur and Whiskey Enthusiast.  Ryan is a Principal Program Manager at Microsoft, working in the Visual Studio Client Tools team where he looks after HTML, CSS and JavaScript development. He comes from a 15 year career in web standards development & advocacy as an entrepreneur, developer and graphic designer. Today, he focuses primarily on mobile app development using web technologies and Apache Cordova. Seriously, if you want to know what is cross-platform or hybrid app, than he is one of the person you should see. Ask him! 

GOODIES There will be a surprise from the community members! I can only tell you this... this thing, you can make call with it, the other one, you can save files on it! Others, you can wear it. That's it! :) Anyone of you can have this, well after you can answer the questions from the speakers. Very limited, so better learn about Microsoft Edge, Apache Cordova, HTML5, Azure and Visual Studio 2015. Also there will be some light refreshment as well (food)!
events.location: NTUC Auditorium, Level 7 NTUC Centre, One Marina Boulevard, Singapore

events.name: ArtScience Late
events.description:
Strangeweather Movement Group with Andy Yang: Spooky Action (at a Distance) II
Thursday 19 November
Performance starts at 8pm
ArtScience Museum, Lobby
FREE


For ArtScience Late, Strangeweather Movement Group revisits a 2013 performance work, Spooky Action (at a Distance), in collaboration with visual artist and musician Andy Yang. In Spooky, Strangeweather considers the theory of quantum entanglement, puts it on the backburner, and creates an off-kilter dance performance of impolite improvisation scores and congruent choreography. Yang intercepts the performance with a resounding set installation and what happens next is anyone’s guess. This rendition of Spooky is performed by Bernice Lee, Faye Lim and Andy Yang. Excerpts of the original performance were featured in filmmaker Karol Jalochowski’s documentary, Reality Lost, which was commissioned by NUS Centre for Quantum
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: Rails Girls Meetup (DevFest.Asia, and the last Rails Girls for 2015)
events.description: **PLEASE REGISTER YOUR INTEREST ON DEVFEST.ASIA TO ATTEND: http://2015.devfest.asia/index.html#Sat21 This will be the last Rails Girls session for 2015, and it's happening as part of the 1.5 weeks long DevFest.Asia. Come along and learn some Ruby on Rails from the Ruby Singapore group! We love beginners so do join us if you are curious about web development and would like to find out more about Ruby and Ruby on Rails. As usual, we have a structured workshop session to guide you all along. For those who have been attending our meetups regularly and/or know the basics of Ruby on Rails, our flexibility will still be there.  If you'd like to work on your project or run through concepts with guidance, our coaches are more than happy to help and answer your questions.  We love the enthusiasts! Come and join us at the November Rails Girls meetup! Agenda: • 10:00 - 10:15 Registration • 10:15 - 10:20 Introduction • 10:20 - 10:30 Break into Groups • 10:30 - 13:00 Start to Code  ---------- FAQs ---------- I haven't attended any previous Rails Girls events. Can I still join in this one? Absolutely! We'll guide you through the basics, so don't worry! What should I bring? A working laptop and power supply. Is this free? Yes! But we are not providing any food/coffee. Can I come if I'm not a woman? Rails Girls is designed for women and anyone who self-identifies as a woman. Men are most welcomed as a participant's +1 . Is there an age limit? Nope! Event is full! What should I do? Join the waitlist! We'll let you know when a new slot becomes available.  Also, please update your RVSP if your plans have changed. Someone will really appreciate your slot. :) I'm a professional Rails Developer, can I be a coach? Yes, we are always looking for Ruby/Rails experts to help! Please contact Nathania (nathaniawong89@gmail.com) and DO NOT RSVP to this event. Confirmed coaches: - Winston - Ted Can my company sponsor Rails Girls meetup? Thank you for helping us build an awesome community!  If your company would like to sponsor this meetup, please get in touch with Winston (winston.yongwei@gmail.com).
events.location: The Hub, 128 Prinsep Street, Singapore 188655

events.name: WebAudio Hack Day
events.description:
http://2015.devfest.asia/#Sun15 As a part of DevFest.Asia, we're organising a WebAudio HackDay. It's a day long event where we'll work on projects around WebAudio, WebMIDI for fun and profit. And the end we'll gather and share what we've created. We will have a couple of brief talks at the beginning to introduce and inspire us. We're lucky to have Paul Adenot (who maintains the WebAudio implementation in Firefox) and Matt McKegg (who created the WebAudio School project) to help us throughout the day. Schedule (Tentative) 11:00 : Registration 11:15 : Talk 1 (20-30mins) 11:45 : Talk 2 (20-30mins) 12:15 : Introductions + Ideas 13:00 : Lunch 19:00 : Demos 20:00 : Dinner 20:30 : Performance 



Tickets are sold through DevFest.Asia's website. Please get your tickets here http://2015.devfest.asia/#Sat21 


F.A.Q. Q. What is this WebAudio you speak of? A. WebAudio is a (widely supported) W3C standard for generating, analysing and playing audio in the Browser. Checkout the spec here (http://webaudio.github.io/web-audio-api/) 


Q. Where can I learn more about WebAudio A. WebAudio School is a self-help style tutorial for learning WebAudio (http://mmckegg.github.io/web-audio-school/).  We're also hosting a NodeSchool event as a part of DevFest where we'll be around to guide you while you go through NodeSchool (http://2015.devfest.asia/#Sun15) 


Q. Why are there tickets? A. To cover the cost of food and drinks during the day. We're trying to get delicious healthy food for everyone for lunch and dinner. And maaybe some prizes. 


Q. What shall I bring to this HackDay? A. Please bring you down laptop, headphones and anything else you want to use for your project, like MIDI controllers, Arduino, etc.

events.name: Book Club: Architecture of Open Source – Audacity & Web Distributed Systems
events.description: Read The Architecture of Open Source Applications online. This week we'll be covering the chapters on Audacity and Scalable Web Architecture and Distributed Systems. At the end of each week's meetup we will take a vote to select ~two chapters from any of the three AOSA Volumes available. If there's a particular chapter you want us to cover, attend the next meetup and cast your vote!  "If you are a junior developer, and want to learn how your more experienced colleagues think, these books are the place to start. If you are an intermediate or senior developer, and want to see how your peers have solved hard design problems, these books can help you too." How Book Club Works1. Read the chapter before you come to the meetup.2. Find something in the chapter you found interesting and maybe research it a little more.3. At the meetup, we go around the room and each person gets a chance to tell the group about the thing they found interesting.4. Group discussion and banter ensues! Book club is held at Tim & Wei's residence: 244A Tanjong Katong RdSingapore  437032Singapore Doors open at 6:30, meetup starts at 7. Bring snacks! Feel free to ask questions in the SingaporeJS gitter room: https://gitter.im/SingaporeJS/discussions
events.location: Tim & Wei's Residence, 244A Tanjong Katong Road, Singapore

events.name: dplyr tricks
events.description: Hi everyone, I would like to suggest a dplyr discussion session. My vision is that the expert users in our group could come forward and share some tips and tricks that they have figured out after using dplyr for some time. It would be sort of an open-mic session. As such, it will not be a tutorial on dplyr; but a session to find out and share solutions with others.  If you have some expertise, please get in touch with me to let me what you would be interested to share, and I can arrange a schedule. If each person just talks for 5-10 minutes with a short example, it would be wonderful. For my part, I propose to talk about the following: 1. using dplyr verbs within other functions. (use of the standard evaluation versions of filter, select, etc.) 2. window functions with dplyr. I haven't fixed a date yet, but targeting Nov 18th if possible.
events.location: Microsoft Auditorium (Singapore), One Marina Boulevard, Level 21 Auditorium, Singapore 018989

events.description: Hackware is a monthly meetup for hardware developers and enthusiasts to share hacks and developments in the hardware scene, promote hardware development and to build a community of hardware developers.  Our talks typically include side projects by speakers on electronics, embedded system, radio communications, internet of things, radio frequency and much more! Come and just drop by for all our open and free meetups, make friends with fellow enthusiasts or beginners and feel free to sign up for a talk slot on whatever you are working on. We collaborate with Science Bites!, a science communication initiative in Science Centre Singapore this November to bring you the wonders of astronomy and science in SCS's Digital Planetarium! Agenda & Talks for this meetup: 1. (20min) Astro-photography and hardware (Celestial Portraits)- Remus CJ 2. (20min) TinyMOS (World's first consumer astronomy camera) - Grey Chen Junyang 3. (20min) Gravitational Redshift - Lerh Feng Low 4. (20min) Quantum Astronomy - Tan Peng Kian 5. Announcements by anyone on:- Hiring positions- Available for hire- Other upcoming hardware-related events locally or anywhere else 6. Socialize and Network with other Hackware members and public members Talks : ~20minsLightning Talks : ~5minsAnnouncements: ~1min Sponsors: ♥ Venue provided by Science Center Singapore ♥http://www.science.edu.sg/Pages/SCBHome.aspx

events.name: Security In The World Of CI-CD
events.description: Continuous Delivery (CD) is a set of practices and principles in software engineering aimed at, building, testing, and releasing software, faster and more frequently. These principles help reduce the cost, time and risk of delivering changes, and ultimately value, to customers by allowing for more incremental changes to applications in production. Continuous integration (CI) is the practice, in software engineering, of merging all developer working copies to a shared mainline several times a day. In the same vein, the practice of continuous delivery further extends CI by making sure the software checked in on the mainline is always in a state that can be deployed to users and makes the actual deployment process very rapid. So, in this rapid and fast world of CI-CD, focusing on highly scalable & highly portable software landscape, which offers high usage oriented web apps, the security landscape has really reached to cutting edge point. This talk, will focus on how to posturize security with this fast pace world, covering most of all security verticals. Speaker:Aniket Kulkarni, carries decade+ of software security experience flowing from QA, Development & Architecture.Currently he works as Software Security Architect (Bigdata\Cloud\Mobile\Web), in Autodesk Singapore R&D, one of world class design software developing companies across the globe. For more information about Aniket, kindly get connected with him on linkedin: https://sg.linkedin.com/pub/aniket-kulkarni/10/653/202 , and he will be happy to interact with you for various security related discussions.
events.location: Akamai Singapore office, 1 Raffles Place, #16-61, One Raffles Place Tower 2, Singapore 048616

events.name: December Meetup @ Strata! Get Excited--It's Big!
events.description: We are holding the December BigData/HadoopSG meetup in conjunction with the first Strata + Hadoop World ever held in Asia. We're taking advantage of the speakers that will be in town and have some really, really big names. Doug Cutting (the Father of Hadoop!) will be talking about "From MapReduce to Spark: An Ecosystem Evolves" Abstract: Apache Hadoop was the first software to permit affordable use of petabytes. In the decade since, many other projects have been created around Hadoop's HDFS storage layer and its MapReduce processing engine, forming a rich software ecosystem. Apache Spark now provides a second generation processing engine which greatly improves on Hadoop's MapReduce. Most new applications will now use Spark in place of MapReduce. This transition provides an example of an evolutionary pattern in the data ecosystem that gives it long-term strength. Ted Dunning, Chief Architect at MapR ,Guru of Everything Scalable, Co-Author of Mahout in Action and Noted Beer Drinker. "How Document Databases Simplify Database Design" He will walk though how a real world database can be restructured using nested data structures resulting in a much simpler design that achieves high performance and scalability and is much easier to understand than the original. In addition, He will show how the resulting database can be queried using SQL tools such as Apache Drill, or using API’s in Python, Javascript and Java. And a couple more speakers that will continue to blow your minds...
events.location: Suntec Convention Center, Suntec Convention Center, Singapore

events.name: Productionizing data science at scale (Strata x Hadoop SG Community Event)
events.description: Coming December, we are proud to close the year with our biggest meetup yet - at Strata x Hadoop SG! Registration will open on 8th November, 1230pm. Free event, open to all (no need for strata x hadoop tickets). For folks who wish to attend the full Strata x Hadoop conference, feel free to use our community's discount code UGDSSG for a 20% discount on the tickets. List of panelist & speakers • Albert Bifet (Institut Mines-Télécom) (panel) • Shirshanka Das (Linkedin) (panel) • Wes McKinney (Cloudera) (panel) • Jennifer Marsman (Microsoft) (panel) • Bin Fan (Tachyon Nexus) (tech startup lightning talk) • Fangjin Yang (Imply) (tech startup lightning talk) • Arshak Navruzyan (Argyle Data, Startup.ml) (tech startup lightning talk) Agenda • 530pm-6pm: Networking session • 6pm-6.15pm: Introduction to Memory-centric Distributed Storage System Tachyon and Its Use Case by Bin Fan. • 6.15pm-6.30pm: Introduction to Druid by Fangjin Yang  • 6.30pm-6.45pm: Lightning talk by Arshak Navruzyan  • 6.45pm - 8pm: Panel discussion - Productionizing data science at scale with Albert Bifet, Shirshanka Das, Wes McKinney and Jennifer Marsman. • 8pm - 830pm: Networking session Profile of speakers: Panelist • Albert Bifet is a big data scientist with 10+ years of international experience in research and in leading new open source software projects for business analytics, data mining, and machine learning (Institut Mines-Télécom, Huawei, Yahoo, University of Waikato, UPC). He obtained a Ph.D. from UPC-BarcelonaTech. Albert has worked in Hong Kong, New Zealand, and Europe. At Yahoo Labs, he co-founded Apache SAMOA (Scalable Advanced Massive Online Analysis) in 2013. Apache SAMOAis a distributed streaming machine learning (ML) framework that contains a programing abstraction for distributed streaming ML algorithms. At the WEKA Machine Learning group, he has co-led MOA (Massive Online Analysis) since 2008.  • Shirshanka Das is the architect for LinkedIn’s Data Analytics Infrastructure team. He was among the original authors of a variety of open and closed source projects built at LinkedIn, including Databus, Espresso, and Apache Helix. His current focus at LinkedIn includes all things Hadoop, high-performance distributed OLAP engines, large-scale data ingestion, transformation and movement, and data lineage and discovery. • Wes McKinney is a software engineer at Cloudera and lead developer of Ibis. He is the creator of Python’s pandas library and is the author of Python for Data Analysis. Previously, Wes was the founder and CEO of DataPad. •  Jennifer Marsman is a principal developer evangelist in Microsoft’s Developer and Platform Evangelism group, where she educates developers on Microsoft’s new technologies. In this role, Jennifer is a frequent speaker at software development conferences across the United States. In 2009, Jennifer was chosen as “Techie whose innovation will have the biggest impact” by X-OLOGY for her work with GiveCamps, a weekend-long event where developers code for charity. Prior to becoming a developer evangelist, Jennifer was a software developer in Microsoft’s Natural Interactive Services division. In this role, she earned two patents for her work in search and data mining algorithms. Tech Startup Lightning Talks: Bin Fan is a software engineer at Tachyon Nexus. He is one of the top committers in the open source community of Tachyon project. Prior to Tachyon Nexus, he worked in Google to build the core storage infrastructure and won Google’s Technical Infrastructure award. Bin got his PhD in computer science from Carnegie Mellon University. Talk details: Introduction to Memory-centric Distributed Storage System Tachyon and Its Use Case Memory is the key to fast Big Data processing. This has been realized by many, and frameworks such as Spark and Shark already leverage memory performance. As data sets continue to grow, storage is increasingly becoming a critical bottleneck in many workloads. To address this need, we have developed Tachyon, a memory centric fault-tolerant distributed file system, which enables reliable file sharing at memory-speed across cluster frameworks, such as Spark and MapReduce. Tachyon caches working set files in memory, and enables different jobs/queries and frameworks to access cached files at memory speed. Tachyon as an open-source system has more than 160 contributors from over 50 institutions, including IBM, Yahoo, Intel, Redhat, Baidu, and Tachyon Nexus. In the presentation, we will also explore several potential industry use cases enabled by the new features.  Fangjin Yang is a co-author of the open source Druid project and a co-founder of Imply, a data analytics startup based in San Francisco. Previously, he held senior engineering positions at Metamarkets and Cisco Systems. Fangjin holds a BASc in Electrical Engineering and a MASc in Computer Engineering from the University of Waterloo, Canada.  Arshak Navruzyan has served in product management and engineering leadership roles at Argyle Data, Alpine Data Labs, Endeca, and Oracle. He is a contributor to the Apache Accumulo project and the organizer of the San Francisco Machine Learning Meetup group. Arshak’s objective is to make machine learning accessible to any organization or individual that wants to transform the world through data. With this aim, he cofounded Startup.ML.
events.location: Suntec Singapore Convention & Exhibition Centre Room 321 - 322 (Level 3), 1 Raffles Boulevard, Suntec City, Singapore 03959, Level 3

events.name: Why ignoring digital perf can cost digital agencies & marketers a lot of money?
events.description: Today’s websites are no longer solely marketing channels, they are critical production factors. If a website fails to deliver a satisfactory customer experience the entire value delivery chain is broken, and a company will not generate revenue regardless of product quality or value proposition.Mastering digital performance is one of the leading challenges of the web economy, and requires a joint effort between IT and the lines of business. It means measuring and managing the end-to-end transaction delivery and translating it into actionable information. Ultimately user experience is your best success metric. If you’re not proactively addressing digital performance issues, users are more likely to take their complaints to their social streams than to call-in and report it. Join our digital performance meetup where, Dave Anderson, Marketing Director, Dynatrace APAC discusses how Digital Performance analytic can optimise the users experience of your website or applications and improve conversions.
events.location: Lime house, 2 Jiak Chuan road 089260, Singapore

events.name: Sunday Showcase
events.description:
Sunday Showcase allows visitors unique access to cutting edge projects being undertaken by different tertiary institutions across Singapore. The series invites the creators and their work into ArtScience Museum on a Sunday each month. The creators are on hand throughout the afternoon to talk with visitors about their inventions, their creative process, and to facilitate visitors' interaction with the projects. There is something for everyone in this hands-on, accessible showcase series.

Innovati50n reconstructed @ ArtScience museum
An Interlude of Science meets Art by A*STAR & NAFA
(Workshops and ‘pop up’ talks throughout the day)
Saturday and Sunday, 5 & 6 December
10am - 7pm
ArtScience Museum, Level 4
FREE


The Agency of Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR) & the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (NAFA) have created 17 science-inspired exhibits using
an array of artistic techniques such as fine art, digital art, photography, sculpture and others. Meet the scientists and artists behind this creative showcase of Singapore’s scientific innovations and get hands-on with our unique Science-Art workshops and demos.
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: Micro Hack Mondays
events.description: A space to meet like-minded people in the media & from the developer beat every first Monday of the month over food & drinks. Perfect for anyone who has a story or an idea that could be told interactively but doesn't know where or how to get started. Or, for anyone who has a new code or library to try out but doesn't have a story angle yet. More information to come - we'll send out announcements soon.
events.location: ST Innovation Lab - SPH, 1000 Toa Payoh North, Singapore

events.name: EML30 Music Festival
events.description:
In celebration of NUS Electronic Music Lab's 30th anniversary, we are holding the EML30 Music Festival on the 12th December at Lepark Singapore from 12pm to 6pm.

EML30 Music Festival will play host to 2, hour-long music forums to discuss the eco-system of electronic music in Singapore beyond 2015, amongst varsity institutional groups and industry leaders respectively.

In addition, there will be 4 hours of original electronic music by our artists, such as Ocean's Children, Kids With Laptops, Mitch Advent, nanowander, Brannlum and many more throughout the afternoon, spanning a multitude of genres accompanied by stunning visuals.

Food and drinks can be purchased at Lepark, so be sure to enjoy the delicious food and tasteful craft beers while you catch the show.

TICKET PRICES:

EML Starter Pack (Whilst Stocks Last) - FREE
Starter Pack to receive a EML Wristband and Sticker (Includes RSVP)

EML Silver Pack - $29.95
You will receive the following items: Exclusive EML30 T-Shirt (Pre-Order Only) and EML Starter Pack (Wristband + Stickers)

EML Gold Pack - $111.95
Exclusive Limited Edition EML30 T-Shirt (Pre-Order Only), EML T-Shirt, EML Drawstring Bag, EML Starter Pack, EML Albums and Cassette Tapes
events.location: Lepark

events.name: Hackware v1.4
events.description: Hackware is a monthly meetup for hardware developers and enthusiasts to share hacks and developments in the hardware scene, promote hardware development and to build a community of hardware developers. Our talks typically include side projects by speakers on electronics, embedded system, radio communications, internet of things, radio frequency and much more! Come and just drop by for all our open and free meetups, make friends with fellow enthusiasts or beginners and feel free to sign up for a talk slot on whatever you are working on. Agenda & Talks for this meetup: 1. (20min) Design for Manufacturing - Daniël J Ellis2. (10min) Tictactoe playing robotic arm using OpenCV - Juan Miguel Jimeno3. (10min) IoT hardware with Meteor Javascript - Rick Behl4. (10min) What has India got to do with the Maker Movement? - Kenneth Lim 5. Announcements by anyone on:- Hiring positions- Available for hire- Other upcoming hardware-related events locally or anywhere else6. Socialize and Network with other Hackware members Talks : ~20minsLightning Talks : ~5minsAnnouncements: ~1min Venue sponsors: Thank you IDA Singapore, Sandcrawler ♥
events.location: IDA @ Sandcrawler, 1 Fusionopolis View, #08-02 Sandcrawler, 138577, Singapore
